We still need a comprehensive approach.
 
This must include thoughtful measures to ease banking restrictions while also maintaining sanctions to prevent money from flowing to the Taliban. (4/4)

The result is Afghans can‚Äôt access their money to buy food.
 
Unfreezing funds for humanitarian aid could help ‚Äî IF aid flows fast enough.
 
But without addressing the banking problem, that alone won‚Äôt solve the long-term issue: the viability of the Afghan economy.  (3/4)

The famine is the result of a liquidity crisis.
 
After the Taliban takeover in August sanctions (US and UN) effectively crippled the economy by stopping the flow of money.
 
Afghan money is also tied up by the 9/11 victim survivor lawsuit. (2/4)

Last month, I joined @RepMalinowski and @RepMeijer in calling for a comprehensive response to Afghanistan‚Äôs economic collapse and famine, including a release of funds.
 
Today, @POTUS announced an important first step in that process.

We must show support for a resistance movement if Russia invades. 

And not just armed resistance‚Äî it must include ongoing, direct support to Ukrainian civil society, independent media, & human rights efforts.

(6/6)

3‚É£ The US must maintain robust diplomacy while preparing to reinforce the Eastern flank of NATO with a large multinational force. @POTUS is already doing this. 

This would reassure Europe & show Putin that an invasion would only strengthen the NATO alliance, not weaken it.
(5/6)

2‚É£ The US must pass comprehensive sanctions that would only take effect AFTER an invasion. 

Putin‚Äôs biggest fear is looking weak.

(4/6)

Ukrainians will fight for their freedom if they have the tools.

We must move faster.

Four ideas for next steps:
